description:
Aeromonas bivalvium is a species of Gram-negative, rod-shaped, facultatively anaerobic bacteria that belongs to the genus Aeromonas. This species was first isolated from the gut of bivalve mollusks, such as clams and oysters, hence the name "bivalvium."

Aeromonas bivalvium is a psychrotrophic (cold-loving) bacterium, capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 4°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 28°C. It is oxidase-positive and can ferment a variety of carbohydrates, producing acids as byproducts.

This species is known to be ubiquitous in aquatic environments, including freshwater, estuarine, and marine habitats. It is commonly found associated with the microbiome of various aquatic organisms, particularly bivalve mollusks, which can serve as a reservoir for the bacteria.

Aeromonas bivalvium is considered an opportunistic pathogen, as it has been implicated in causing diseases in both humans and aquatic animals, such as gastroenteritis, wound infections, and septicemia. Its potential pathogenicity is attributed to the production of various virulence factors, including extracellular enzymes, toxins, and adhesins.

The identification and study of Aeromonas bivalvium are important in the fields of food safety, aquaculture, and environmental microbiology, as it can provide insights into the ecology and potential impacts of this bacterial species in aquatic ecosystems and its interactions with host organisms.
